title.narrative: Power of Women Collectives in Social Economic Development

description.narrative: The project started by forming and strengthening 11 cooperatives. To ensure the project's smooth functioning and performance, 11 strategic plans were developed for those cooperatives and their by-laws reviewed as well. Training programs were conducted on different disciplines such as cooperative values and principles, by-laws and constitution of the cooperative. Since the project also benefits the enhancement of youth employment, a youth career guidance training program was conducted as well. The gender committees were formed under each cooperative, and provided awareness sessions as well for the committee leaders on gender base violence and women rights CEDOW convention. Seven women were selected from each cooperative to create the model home gardens and provided exposure visit and basic training on developing the model home gardens (77 home gardens). Further, the training sessions were conducted for the small-scale farmers to improve their knowledge, skills and capacities on good agricultural practices. The good governance and good governance tool introductory sessions were conducted for the cooperative leaders in order to increase the capacity of the village cooperatives and to develop management, leadership and good governance. Further, the collection of baseline data was completed.

The project will be implemented by RPK in Anuradhapura district, targeting rural and war-affected communities in marginalised villages in three divisions and targeting 15 primary cooperatives. Thus, the project will improve and increase the institutional and individual capacities and skills, promote eco-friendly farming and good practices among the small-scale farmers, women empowerment and improvement of women leadership, address gender-based violence issues, promote sustainable cooperative businesses and women entrepreneurship, increase access to government services and enable environment for a rights-based approach. The project aims to benefit 1600 women and 700 men through the process and eradicate poverty and uplift their living standard. The project will result in a sustainable socio-economic development of poor and marginalised communities with equal rights in selected areas by which organised women and girls from rural communities are empowered with increased access to land, financial resources and improved living conditions.
